customer_name: Houston Interactive Aquarium and Animal Preserve
customer_addr:
5440 N Sam Houston Parkway East
Houston, TX 77032

citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there were several outdoor animal enclosures with standing water and excessive muddy
conditions. The warthog and two mini pigs (in an enclosure together separate from the warthog) had mud covering more
than fifty percent of their enclosure, where it was thick, of a clingy consistency, rutted areas, and mud puddles that varied
in size throughout. Lack of adequate drainage can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals contained
therein as it creates an environment that can foster the following: health issues that arise from the proliferation of
organisms like bacteria and fungi; injuries; foot problems, etc. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate
excess water. The method of drainage shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating
to pollution control or the protection of the environment. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the
inspection: addition of sandy substrate; draining the water; and crushed granite in the warthog enclosure.
Correct by: December 13, 2024

During the inspection, excessive amounts of rodent feces was found in various areas of the facility in food storage areas.
Feces was found atop multiple bags of feed in the feed shipping container, tack shed, upstairs mammal prep area, and
atop the food storage lids in the hoof stock tack shed. Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact
the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. A safe
and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and
maintained. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the inspection: elimination of rodent access points
of the shipping container, and by increasing the number and frequency of checking bait stations.
Correct by: December 19, 2024

At the time of inspection, the ostrich enclosure had standing water and excessive muddy conditions. More than fifty
percent of the enclosure was affected, whereby the mud was thick, of a clingy consistency, rutted areas, and mud puddles
that varied in size throughout. There was an area along the front fence line that had large puddles of water. Lack of
adequate drainage can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals contained therein as it creates an
environment that can foster the following: health issues that arise from the proliferation of organisms like bacteria and
fungi; injuries; foot problems, etc. Housing facilities must be equipped with disposal and drainage systems that are
constructed and operated so animal wastes and water are rapidly eliminated so the animals have the option of remaining
dry. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the inspection: drainage of the water; repair of a broken
sprinkler; removal of the mud and the addition of crushed granite.
Correct by: December 13, 2024

In the feed shipping container where the animal diets are stored, there were two large bags of expired bird food. The
Mazuri Crane diet expired on November 7, 2024, and the Mazuri Soft Bill/Toucan diet expired on August 6, 2024. Both
diets could have been utilized at any time and were not identified as being expired. Expired food loses its nutritive value,
can foster contamination via mold and toxins, which can subject the birds to health issues. The food must be wholesome,
palatable to the birds, and free of contamination. It must be of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain a healthy
condition and weight range of the bird and to meet its normal daily nutritional requirements. During the inspection, the
facility began the following corrective actions: the expired food was discarded; the rest of the animal food was inspected
for expiration; the protocol for the inspection of new food was modified; and discontinuation of a particular diet supplier.
Correct by: December 13, 2024
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or January 8, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.126(d) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
At the time of inspection, there were several outdoor animal enclosures with standing water and excessive muddy 
conditions. The warthog and two mini pigs (in an enclosure together separate from the warthog) had mud covering more 
than fifty percent of their enclosure, where it was thick, of a clingy consistency, rutted areas, and mud puddles that varied 
in size throughout. Lack of adequate drainage can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals contained 
therein as it creates an environment that can foster the following: health issues that arise from the proliferation of 
organisms like bacteria and fungi; injuries; foot problems, etc. A suitable method shall be provided to rapidly eliminate 
excess water. The method of drainage shall comply with applicable Federal, State, and local laws and regulations relating 
to pollution control or the protection of the environment. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the 
inspection: addition of sandy substrate; draining the water; and crushed granite in the warthog enclosure.  
 
Correct by: December 13, 2024 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
During the inspection, excessive amounts of rodent feces was found in various areas of the facility in food storage areas. 
Feces was found atop multiple bags of feed in the feed shipping container, tack shed, upstairs mammal prep area, and 
atop the food storage lids in the hoof stock tack shed. Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact 
the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. A safe 
and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and 
maintained. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the inspection: elimination of rodent access points 
of the shipping container, and by increasing the number and frequency of checking bait stations.  
 
Correct by: December 19, 2024 
3.150(g) 
   
Facilities, general.

At the time of inspection, the ostrich enclosure had standing water and excessive muddy conditions. More than fifty 
percent of the enclosure was affected, whereby the mud was thick, of a clingy consistency, rutted areas, and mud puddles 
that varied in size throughout. There was an area along the front fence line that had large puddles of water. Lack of 
adequate drainage can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals contained therein as it creates an 
environment that can foster the following: health issues that arise from the proliferation of organisms like bacteria and 
fungi; injuries; foot problems, etc. Housing facilities must be equipped with disposal and drainage systems that are 
constructed and operated so animal wastes and water are rapidly eliminated so the animals have the option of remaining 
dry. The facility initiated the following corrective actions during the inspection: drainage of the water; repair of a broken 
sprinkler; removal of the mud and the addition of crushed granite.  
 
Correct by: December 13, 2024 
3.155(a) 
   
Feeding 
In the feed shipping container where the animal diets are stored, there were two large bags of expired bird food. The 
Mazuri Crane diet expired on November 7, 2024, and the Mazuri Soft Bill/Toucan diet expired on August 6, 2024. Both 
diets could have been utilized at any time and were not identified as being expired. Expired food loses its nutritive value, 
can foster contamination via mold and toxins, which can subject the birds to health issues. The food must be wholesome, 
palatable to the birds, and free of contamination. It must be of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain a healthy 
condition and weight range of the bird and to meet its normal daily nutritional requirements. During the inspection, the 
facility began the following corrective actions: the expired food was discarded; the rest of the animal food was inspected 
for expiration; the protocol for the inspection of new food was modified; and discontinuation of a particular diet supplier.  
 
Correct by: December 13, 2024 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or January 8, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
